question.title: Will the community prediction be higher than 23.00% on 2026-02-28 for the Metaculus question "Will the composition of the US Supreme Court change in 2026?"?
question.description:
Metaculus is a crowdsourced forecast aggregation platform where humans and bots compete to predict future events. Each question on Metaculus has a community prediction that aggregates all user's forecasts. As of this question launch, this aggregation is calculated as a median of user forecasts weighted by recency. 

--------------------------------

Below are some details about the original Metaculus question: 
- Question URL: https://www.metaculus.com/questions/41072
- Original question title: Will the composition of the US Supreme Court change in 2026?
- The current community prediction as of 2026-02-16: 23.00%

Original resolution criteria: 
> This question will resolve as **Yes** if, before January 1, 2027, any of the following takes place:
> 
> * a sitting US Supreme Court Justice officially leaves office
> * a federal bill that changes the number of seats in the US Supreme Court is enacted, regardless of the effective date.

Original fine print: 
> A Justice announcing their intention to leave will not resolve this question before the exit takes place.
> 
> The composition of the US Supreme Court as of December 2025 is the following:
> 
> * Chief Justice John Roberts
> * Associate Justice Clarence Thomas
> * Associate Justice Samuel Alito
> * Associate Justice Sonia Sotomayor
> * Associate Justice Elena Kagan
> * Associate Justice Neil Gorsuch
> * Associate Justice Brett Kavanaugh
> * Associate Justice Amy Coney Barrett
> * Associate Justice Ketanji Brown Jackson

Original background: 
> The US Supreme Court has made many monumental decisions in the recent years. Dobbs v. Jackson Women’s Health overturned Roe v. Wade, allowing states to [ban](https://www.guttmacher.org/state-policy/explore/state-policies-abortion-bans) abortions. Trump v. United States [offers](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Trump_v._United_States) US presidents absolute immunity from criminal prosecution for all "official acts" (interpreted broadly) during a presidency. Important cases before the Court at the time of question writing include [Louisiana v. Callais](https://www.metaculus.com/questions/40417/will-scotus-strike-down-louisianas-congressional-map-restoring-gop-lean/), which could strike down a majority-Black congressional district and restore Republican-leaning a map to Louisiana and other Deep South states; and [Learning Resources, Inc. v. Trump](https://www.metaculus.com/questions/39893/scotus-ruling-on-tariffs-in-2025/), in which the Court is to decide on the legality of many of Donald Trump's tariffs imposed in 2025.
> 
> The US Constitution [allows](https://www.law.georgetown.edu/legal-ethics-journal/blog/lifetime-appointments-of-federal-judges-a-double-edged-sword/) Supreme Court justices to serve for life. The Court has a 6-3 Republican majority, with the following configuration: 
> 
> | Justice                                                                      | Age (Dec 2025) | Year of Appointment | Appointed by          |
> | ---------------------------------------------------------------------------- | -------------- | ------------------- | --------------------- |
> | [John G. Roberts, Jr.](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_Roberts)           | 70             | 2005                | George W. Bush (R)    |
> | [Clarence Thomas](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Clarence_Thomas)             | 77             | 1991                | George H. W. Bush (R) |
> | [Samuel A. Alito, Jr.](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Samuel_Alito)           | 75             | 2006                | George W. Bush (R)    |
> | [Sonia Sotomayor](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sonia_Sotomayor)             | 71             | 2009                | Barack Obama (D)      |
> | [Elena Kagan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Elena_Kagan)                     | 65             | 2010                | Barack Obama (D)      |
> | [Neil M. Gorsuch](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Neil_Gorsuch)                | 58             | 2017                | Donald Trump (R)      |
> | [Brett M. Kavanaugh](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Brett_Kavanaugh)          | 60             | 2018                | Donald Trump (R)      |
> | [Amy Coney Barrett](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amy_Coney_Barrett)         | 53             | 2020                | Donald Trump (R)      |
> | [Ketanji Brown Jackson](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ketanji_Brown_Jackson) | 55             | 2022                | Joe Biden (D)         |
> 
> There has been [speculation](https://www.newsweek.com/donald-trump-justice-clarence-thomas-supreme-court-conservative-supermajority-1982850) that conservative Justice Clarence Thomas, now 77, might strategically retire and be replaced by Donald Trump with someone younger while Republicans still have a solid 53-47 majority of the US Senate. There have been similar [calls](https://www.wsj.com/us-news/law/justice-samuel-alito-plans-to-remain-on-supreme-court-f14aac9e) around Samuel Alito, 75. 
> 
> Supreme Court justices are confirmed by a simple majority of the Senate. At the time of this question, the Metaculus Community had Democrats with a [32% chance ](https://www.metaculus.com/questions/36370/us-senate-plurality-after-2026-midterms/)of taking control of the US Senate in the 2026 midterm elections, which would greatly complicate Trump's ability to get his Supreme Court nominees confirmed, if it were to occur.
> 
> Since 1970, 34% of years have had a vacancy in the Supreme Court. A spreadsheet with the listings can be found [here](https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1NjeY3dUxaISl1zvGOHdk1xik7SUrsuHlJGa-QDGn62A/edit?gid=864824442#gid=864824442). 

`{"format":"metaculus_binary_cp_rises","info":{"post_id":41072,"question_id":40777,"last_cp":0.23}}`
question.resolution_criteria: This question will resolve based on the community prediction of the Metaculus question found [here](https://www.metaculus.com/questions/41072) (i.e. the 'target question'). If the community prediction of the target question on 2026-02-28 19:08:43 is higher than 23.00%, this question will resolve to 'Yes'. If it is lower or equal to 23.00%, this question will resolve to 'No'. If the target question has already resolved before this question opens, then this question will be annulled. If the target question resolves after this question opens, but before 2026-02-28 19:08:43, then this question will resolve to the same value as the target question.
